definition.en: Abnormally high sea levels caused by high astronomical tides exacerbated by sea level rise and/or storm surge.

The ability of a system to modify or change its characteristics and behaviours to cope with actual or anticipated stresses. These factors enable the adjustment of responses and behaviours through learning, adaptation and transformation.
Administrative data is the set of units and data derived from an administrative source. (e.g. tax records or Medicare transactions)

citation: [OECD Glossary of Statistical Terms - Administrative data Definition](https://doi.org/10.1787/9789264055087-en)

definition.en: Smaller earthquake following the largest earthquake of a series concentrated in a restricted crustal volume.
The vibrations of the Earth caused by the passage of seismic waves radiating from some source of elastic energy.
Relating to cultivation of plants and livestock for consumption and economic benefit.
Data analysis is the process of transforming raw data into usable information, often presented in the form of a published analytical article, in order to add value to the statistical output.

citation: [OECD Glossary of Statistical Terms - Data analysis Definition](https://doi.org/10.1787/9789264055087-en)

definition.en: Underwater depth of ocean floors, lake floors, or river floors.
Hazards of an organic origin: pathogenic microorganisms, toxins and bioactive substances that occur either naturally or are deliberately or unintentionally released.
Human-made surroundings, structures and supporting infrastructure to facilitate life, health, work and play.
Visibly blackened land surface left after a fire has burned through vegetation.
Unplanned vegetation fire. A generic term which includes grass fires, forest fires and scrub fires both with and without a suppression objective.
A census is a survey conducted on the full set of observation objects belonging to a given population or universe. (e.g. the Australian Census of Population and Housing)

The climate of a locality is the synthesis of the day-to-day values of the meteorological elements that affect the locality. Climatic data are usually expressed in terms of an individual calendar month or season and are determined over a period (usually about 30 years) long enough to ensure that representative values for the month or season are obtained. This may include the future expectation of long term weather, in the order of weeks, months or years ahead.
The simulated response of the climate system to a scenario of future emission or concentration of greenhouse gases (GHGs) and aerosols, generally derived using climate models.
The transition zone between the land and the sea.

A community, like a family, can contribute to a person's wellbeing e.g. support and care for individuals or by helping give a sense of identity and security. Like 'family', a definition of 'community' can vary greatly. A community can be based on:
- location
- where you live or work
- those who you have immediate family ties with (by blood and/or marriage)
- shared values
- traditions
- interests
- lifestyles
- religious groups
- school communities

The boundary of a community extends beyond a physical location.

citation: [Family and Community - Frameworks for Australian Social Statistics ](https://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/by%20Subject/4160.0.55.001~Jun%202015~Main%20Features~Family%20and%20community~10014)

definition.en: The issues arising from the impact of an event. For example, the consequences of road closures due to a flood event include lack of access to residences or blockage in supply lines. A single form of impact may have multiple consequences across different domains.
The process generally associated with warm rising air and the formation of cloud. Local breezes, wind and thunderstorms are a result of convection in the atmosphere.
Cloud formed through convection, particularly cumulonimbus* and cumulus* clouds.

The ability of people, organizations and systems, using available skills and resources, to manage adverse conditions, risk or disasters. The capacity to cope requires continuing awareness, resources and good management, both in normal times as well as during disasters or adverse conditions. Coping capacities contribute to the reduction of disaster risks.
The physical structures, facilities, networks, lifelines and other assets which provide services that are essential to the social and economic functioning of a community or society.
Level of damage expressed as the ratio of repair cost to total replacement cost. Typically used to describe physical or structural losses for assets.
Waves that may lead to significant beach erosion or damage to property.
Sustained winds of gale force (63 km/h) or more, or wind gusts of 90 km/h or more (100 km/h or more in Tasmania).
Data are measurements or observations that are collected as a source of information. There are a variety of different types of data, and different ways to represent data.
Visual presentation of data to communicate the stories contained in the dataset.
A complete collection of all observations.
Statistical data relating to the population and particular groups within it.
Sustained winds of storm force (89 km/h) or more, or wind gusts of 125 km/h or more.
The monetary value of total or partial destruction of physical assets existing in the affected area. Direct economic loss is nearly equivalent to physical damage.
Total economic impact that consists of direct economic loss and indirect economic loss.

Serious disruption of the functioning of a community or a society at any scale due to hazardous events interacting with conditions of exposure, vulnerability and capacity, leading to one or more of the following: human, material, economic and environmental losses and impacts.

citation: [Hazard Definition and Classification Review: Technical Report

definition.en: The potential loss of life, injury, or destroyed or damaged assets which could occur to a system, society or a community in a specific period of time, determined probabilistically as a function of hazard, exposure, vulnerability and capacity.

Activities and measures to reduce or lessen existing disaster risk or to limit the adverse impacts of a hazardous event. Mitigation differs from prevention in that it is reactive to an identified and currently existing risk or impending threat. Thus, the activities mitigate for specific threats, instead of general risk prevention.

Activities with an intention to avoid potential adverse impacts of hazardous events. While certain disaster risks cannot be eliminated, prevention aims at reducing vulnerability and exposure in such contexts where, as a result, the risk of disaster is removed.

Disaster risk reduction is aimed at preventing new and reducing existing disaster risk and managing residual risk, all of which contribute to strengthening resilience and therefore to the achievement of sustainable development.
Movement of the population as a direct result of a hazard, including evacuations and permanent relocations of people due to a disaster.
Local, low-voltage electricity network to transport electricity from transmission networks to end users (households and businesses). This includes powerlines and power poles.
The social, economic, natural and built domains for information.
Geographic extent of a weather or climate modelling system where the variables of a model are calculated.
Prolonged absence or marked deficiency of precipitation (rain).

A dust storm happens when strong wind picks up dust and dirt from the ground, raises it into the atmosphere and carries it over an extensive area. Dust storms can trigger health problems for some people and cause disruption to transport due to poor visibility.

A dwelling is considered to be a suite of rooms contained within a building intended for long-term residential use, possessing cooking and bathing/shower facilities as building fixtures. A house is considered to be a detached residential building containing a single dwelling.

Buildings that contain one or more dwellings, intended for the provision of long-term accommodation. This includes detached houses, semi-detached houses, townhouses and apartments. Ancillary outbuildings not containing dwellings built adjacent to existing residential buildings, such as garden sheds, gazebos and free standing garages, are treated as residential buildings.
Other types of accommodation such as hotels, holiday rentals, hospitals and aged care facilities (excluding retirement villages) are classified as non-residential.

A method that derives local- to regional-scale (10 to 100 km) information from larger-scale models or data analyses, using the output of regional climate models, global models with variable spatial resolution or high-resolution global models.
Production and consumption of goods and services - productivity, financial systems and the economy.
Height of the ground above or below a fixed reference point, most commonly a reference geoid or mean sea level.
The naturally occurring living and non-living components of the earth, together constituting the biophysical environment, which may provide benefits to humanity.
Hazards that arise through degradation of the natural systems and ecosystem services upon which humanity depends.
The physical structures, facilities, networks, lifelines and other assets which provide services that are essential to the social and economic functioning of a community or society.
An estimate is a value that is inferred for a population based on data collected from a sample of units from that population.
An incident or situation, which occurs in a particular place during a particular interval of time.
The probability that an event of a given magnitude, or any greater magnitude, will occur. Exceedance probability relates to a given time period, commonly one year.

The location and characteristics of assets: people, infrastructure, buildings, agriculture, environmental assets, production capacities and other tangible human assets that may be at risk from a hazard across the natural, social, economic and built domains.

Family is often thought of as a group of people who are related through blood or marriage, and often live together. However, the definition of what a family is, and the way it is structured and functions, can vary greatly depending on the individual, community and culture. Family can range from the people living together in the same dwelling, to an extended network which crosses state and country boundaries. The structure can also vary. Family can be made up of intact, blended, one parent, and step families.

citation: [Family and Community - Frameworks for Australian Social Statistics](https://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/by%20Subject/4160.0.55.001~Jun%202015~Main%20Features~Family%20and%20community~10014)

definition.en: A flood that rises quite rapidly with little or no advance warning, usually as a result of an intense rainfall over a small area or, possibly, an ice jam, a dam failure, etc.

Hazards resulting from the state and behaviour of the Earth's atmosphere, its interaction with the land and oceans, the weather and climate it produces and the resulting distribution of water resources.
The geographic extent of land that has been, or might be, flooded.
A statement of prediction of weather variables based on a combination of computer generated materials and forecaster-input. Usually on a time scale of hours to days.
Forecasts speculate future values for the population with a certain level of confidence, based on current and past values as an expectation (prediction) of what will happen.

The level of detail at which data has been collected (e.g. temporal or spatial). Granularity of data refers to the size in which data fields are sub-divided, where 'granular data, fine granularity, high granularity, small granularity' would refer to highly detailed data which may be more useful for drawing insights about specific events by time or place.
Precipitation that originates in convective clouds, such as cumulonimbus, in the form of balls or irregular pieces of ice.
A process, phenomenon or human activity that may cause loss of life, injury or other health impacts, property damage, social and economic disruption or environmental degradation.
Surf that creates unsafe conditions for swimmers, rock fishers and boaters. The thresholds for hazardous surf are based on wave height, swell direction and swell period and vary regionally
A period of abnormally hot weather lasting several days.
The highest level of water that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and any combination of astronomical conditions. This level may not be reached every year.
The periodic rise and fall of water along the coast due to gravitational interactions between the moon, sun and the earth.

A household is defined as one or more persons, at least one of whom is at least 15 years of age, usually resident in the same private dwelling.
Note: a household does not necessarily represent a family.

citation: [2901.0 - Census of Population and Housing: Census Dictionary

definition.en: A rigid, fixed and permanent structure which has a roof intended primarily to house people.
Impact forecasting combines a forecast of a weather or climate hazard and an assessment of possible impacts, including when, where and how likely the impacts are.

citation: [UNDRR The Future of Forecasts: Impact-based Forecasting for Early Action ](https://globalplatform.undrr.org/sites/default/files/2022-02/The%20future%20of%20forecasts%20-%20Impact%20based%20forecasting%20for%20early%20action.pdf?startDownload=true)

definition.en: A decline in economic value added as a consequence of direct economic loss and/or human and environmental impacts. This includes micro- meso- and macroeconomic impacts. Indirect losses can occur inside or outside the hazard area and often have a time lag.

The impacts of a disaster that are not due to the direct, physical outcomes of a hazard event (including declines in output or revenue, and impact on wellbeing of people), and generally arise from disruptions to the flow of goods and services as a result of a disaster e.g. business interruption, lost income.

citation: [Understanding Risk: Evolution of Disaster Risk Assessment (GFDRR

definition.en: The direct, adverse outcomes of a hazard event on an asset, such as the amount of damage to a building due to the effects of wind, water, fire or ground shaking.

Activities relating to the production of goods, services and materials. Typically covers agriculture, forestry and fishing, mining, manufacturing, electricity, gas, water and waste services, construction, wholesale trade and retail trade.

citation: [Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC)] (https://www.abs.gov.au/statistics/classifications/australian-and-new-zealand-standard-industrial-classification-anzsic/latest-release)

definition.en: Any fixed-in-place constructed physical asset that does not have a roof. This includes road, bridges, rail lines, harbours, mine facilities, pipelines, sewerage, drainage, telecommunications, water storage and supply, recreation facilities, other heavy industry and electircity generation, transmission and distribution lines.

historyNote.none: Modified from the ABS Engineering Construction Glossary; [Glossary]  (https://www.abs.gov.au/methodologies/engineering-construction-activity-australia-methodology/dec-2021#glossary)

definition.en: Integration is a statistical process whereby units or industries are combined to a larger unit under consideration of the flows of intermediate deliveries that may exist between the individual units.
Value-added analysis, supported by further interpretation to make the analysis more digestible for users (e.g. through visual aids like story maps, dashboards and mapping).
The result of water covering land that would normally remain dry. This can be caused by riverine flooding, flash flooding, tsunami, storm tide, astronomical tides or other hydrometeorological events.

A mudslide induced by volcanic eruption either at the time of the eruption (by the mixing of hot gases, melted ice or water, and ash) or years later (by the failure of volcanic ash deposits in the presence of heavy rain).
Land cover refers to the observed physical and biological cover of the Earth’s surface and includes natural vegetation and abiotic (non-living) surfaces.
Land tenure is the manner in which a party holds or occupies an area of land. It is a way of identifying who has the right to use and occupy land in accordance with the different types of ownership.

Land use reflects both (i) the activities undertaken and (ii) the institutional arrangements put in place; for a given area for the purposes of economic production, or the maintenance and restoration of environmental functions.
Hail larger than 2 cm in diameter.

Out-dated system that continues to be used by an organisation because it still performs the functions it was initially intended to do. Legacy systems often no longer have support or maintenance and have limited opportunities for development.
Process of soil and sand behaving like a dense fluid rather than a wet solid mass during an earthquake.

Hazards with a geological origin, including seismogenic (earthquake-related), volcanogenic (lava flow, ash fall, lahars, pyroclastic flows) and near-surface processes (e.g. mass movement, landslides, sinkholes).

Local Government Areas cover legally designated parts of a State or Territory for which incorporated local governing bodies have responsibility. Local Government Areas are an ABS Mesh Block approximation of gazetted local government boundaries as defined by each state and territory. ABS approximations of administrative boundaries do not match official legal boundaries and should only be used for statistical purposes.

Quantified impact of a disaster event. Can be monetary, physical or intangible. Can relate to losses in a single element or across domains. For example, the loss associated with a flood event may include insured losses to residential, commercial and industrial assets, losses associated with business interruption.
The lowest tide level that can be predicted to occur under average meteorological conditions and any combination of astronomical conditions. This level may not be reached every year.

In addition to Moderate flooding, extensive rural areas and/or urban areas are inundated. Many buildings may be affected above the floor level. Properties and towns are likely to be isolated and major rail and traffic routes closed. Evacuation of flood affected areas may be required. Utility services may be impacted.

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: The overflowing by water of the normal confines of a stream or other body of water, or the accumulation of water by drainage over areas which are not normally submerged.
Relating to the sea or ocean.

Metadata is the information that defines and describes data. It is often referred to as data about data or information about data because it provides data users with information about the purpose, processes, and methods involved in the data collection.
Theory and methods of data collection, processing and analysis.

Flooding that causes inconvenience. Low-lying areas next to water courses are inundated. Minor roads may be closed and low-level bridges submerged. In urban areas inundation may affect some backyards and buildings below the floor level as well as bicycle and pedestrian paths. In rural areas removal of stock and equipment may be required.

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: The construction of physical, conceptual or mathematical simulations of the real world. Models help to show relationships between processes (physical, economic or social) and may be used to predict the effects of changes in land use. (Note utility is much broader than land use)

In addition to Minor flooding, the area of inundation is more substantial. Main traffic routes may be affected. Some buildings may be affected above the floor level. Evacuation of flood affected areas may be required. In rural areas removal of stock is required.

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: The specific contexts where hazardous events may occur simultaneously, cascadingly or cumulatively over time, and taking into account the potential interrelated effects.
Multispectral imaging combines a number of spectral imaging bands of relatively large bandwidth into a single optical system to enable extraction of additional details.
Landscapes, seascapes, ecosystems, agricultural lands and animal life.
The tides when the moon and sun are at right angles to each other (in relation to the earth), the effect of the attraction is somewhat reduced leading to a smaller tidal range.
The record of the measurement or assessment of a particular meteorological variable obtained at a specific time.
In statistics an observation would mean a single data point within a dataset.

Depth of water (in metres) at a river height measuring gauge located along the river. In most cases, a zero reading is the lowest water level that is reached during dry conditions. In many tidal areas, as well as a few inland areas, river levels are expressed in metres above mean sea level or Australian Height Datum (AHD).

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: The study of the physical, chemical, and biological features of the ocean.
Highest river height (in metres) observed during a flood event at the specified site on the river.

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: Physical characteristics of an asset that influence the structural performance of that asset in a hazard event.

Australia's estimated resident population (ERP) includes all people who usually live in Australia (regardless of nationality, citizenship or visa status), with the exception of people present for foreign military, consular or diplomatic reasons.
Note: not to be confused with statistical population which has a different meaning.

Height (in metres) to which the river is predicted to rise at the river gauge referred to in the warning. The actual depth of flood water will vary across the floodplain. Knowledge of past flood events, as well as estimates of flood levels from flood studies, are used by local Councils, emergency services and landowners to determine which areas are likely to be flooded from the predicted river height. The accuracy of these predictions will depend on a number of factors, including the type of flood forecasting model and its input data. Predicted river heights are subject to forecasting error and are regularly updated as more information becomes available during a flood event.

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: Arrangements to ensure that, should a crisis occur, the required resources, capabilities and services can be efficiently mobilised and deployed
Measures to eliminate or reduce the severity of a hazard or crisis.

A projection indicates what the future changes in a population would be if the assumptions about future trends actually occur. These assumptions are often based on patterns of change which have previously occurred. A projection is not making a prediction or forecast about what is going to happen, it is indicating what would happen if the assumptions which underpin the projection actually occur.
Qualitative data are measures of 'types' and may be represented by a name, symbol, or a number code.
Quantitative data are measures of values or counts and are expressed as numbers.

The medium- and long-term rebuilding and restoration of critical infrastructure, services, housing, facilities and livelihoods required for the full functioning of a community, or a society affected by a disaster.

Short and medium-term measures to restore or improve the livelihoods, health, economic, physical, social, cultural and environmental assets, systems and activities, of a disaster-affected community or society, aligning with the principles of sustainable development and ‘build back better’ to avoid or reduce future disaster risk.

The average time interval at which events equal to or greater than a certain magnitude would recur if existing natural regimes continued without change. Recurrence interval is a function of exceedance probability.
Meeting the essential needs of food, water, shelter and medicines for people affected by a crisis event.
Intended to provide accommodation to people.

The ability of a system, community or society exposed to hazards to resist, absorb, accommodate, adapt to, transform and recover from the effects of a hazard in a timely and efficient manner, including through the preservation and restoration of its essential basic structures and functions through risk management.
Actions taken in anticipation of, during, and immediately after an emergency to ensure that its effects are minimised, and that people affected are given immediate relief and support.
Probability of a defined level of impact determined as a function of hazard, exposure, vulnerability and coping capacity. Metrics may include average annualised loss or return period loss levels.

Water level rises to this level may cause the isolation of stock in very low-lying areas. Typically below the minor flood class level, this is the level at which a river alert is issued (where available).

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: A summary of observed river heights (metres) at selected locations and specified times within river basins.

citation: [Flood Warning Services: National flood forecasting and warning service: Water Information: Bureau of Meteorology (bom.gov.au)](http://www.bom.gov.au/water/floods/floodWarningServices.shtml)

definition.en: Images of the Earth captured by a satellite which orbits about the Earth. Data captured through various radiation frequencies (eg. Visible and Infrared), and used to observe (amongst others) the development of weather systems, the landscape and landforms.
The record of the measurement or assessment of a particular variable derived from satellite data.
A hypothetical set of circumstances that describe a disaster event and the related consequences.

The increase in the mean level of the world’s oceans due to the effects of global warming. Relative sea level change refers to how the height of the ocean rises or falls relative to the land at a particular location. In contrast, absolute sea level change refers to the height of the ocean surface above the center of the earth, without regard to whether nearby land is rising or falling.
Impacts arising as a result of the direct impact of a hazard event. For example, fires triggered by ruptured gas mains after an earthquake.

A thunderstorm with winds measuring 48 knots (90 km/h) or greater, 2 cm hail or larger, tornadoes or heavy rain which may lead to flash flooding. Severe thunderstorms may also produce torrential rain and frequent lightning.
A tropical cyclone with maximum 10-minute mean winds of 118 km/h or higher.

An estimate of how well a forecast performs relative to some well-defined reference forecast (baseline) over repeated forecast trials. A skillful forecast system is usually consistently better than the baseline. There are a variety of different methods that can be used to 'score' the level of skill, which highlight different attributes of the forecast.
Estimates produced by modelling larger scale (e.g. state or national level) survey estimates for smaller areas.
Characteristics of a person or group in terms of capacity to anticipate, cope with, resist and recover from impacts of a hazard event.

Events triggered beyond the Earth's atmosphere that impact upon the near-Earth space environment, our technology, and on Earth itself. The primary source of space weather is the Sun, with the greatest disturbances usually caused by solar flares, coronal mass ejections and associated geomagnetic storms.
Relating to or occupying space - location. Spatially enabled data, or data with detailed location information, enables the integration of geospatial and statistical information.
The tides when the moon, sun and earth are in line, their combined attraction is stronger, leading to a larger tidal range.

A statistic is a value that has been produced from a data collection, such as a summary measure, an estimate or projection. Statistical information is data that has been organised to serve a useful purpose.

Statistical Areas Level 1 (SA1s) are designed to maximise the geographic detail available for Census of Population and Housing data while maintaining confidentiality. Most SA1s have a population of between 200 to 800 people.
Hierarchical geographical areas used to release and analyse a range of social, demographic and economic statistics.

Statistical Areas Level 2 (SA2s) are medium-sized general purpose areas built to represent communities that interact together socially and economically. Most SA2s have a population range of 3,000 to 25,000 people.
Statistical Areas Level 3 (SA3s) are designed for the output of regional data and most have populations between 30,000 and 130,000 people.

Statistical Areas Level 4 (SA4s) are designed for the output of a variety of regional data, and represent labour markets and the functional area of Australian capital cities. Most SA4s have a population of over 100,000 people.
Statistical literacy refers to the knowledge and skills that enable data users and producers to understand, evaluate and communicate statistical data and information.

An abnormal rise in sea level over and above the normal (astronomical) tide levels. It can be thought of as the change in the water level due to the presence of a storm. These powerful ocean movements are caused by strong winds piling water up against the coast as a cyclone approaches.

The water level that results from the combination of the storm surge and the normal (astronomical) tide. If the storm surge arrives at the same time as the high tide, the potential risk of inundation, flooding and erosion is greater than at a lower tide. An additional threat at this time could come from the presence of very high waves (wave run-up).
A landslide that occurs under water.
The general term given to movement of material downslope in a mass.

A survey is an investigation about the characteristics of a given population by means of collecting data from a sample of that population and estimating their characteristics through the systematic use of statistical methodology.

Originate from technological or industrial conditions, dangerous procedures, infrastructure failures or specific human activities. Examples include industrial pollution, nuclear radiation, toxic wastes, dam failures, transport accidents, factory explosions, fires and chemical spills. Technological hazards also may arise directly as a result of the impacts of a natural hazard event.

Sudden electrical discharges manifested by a flash of light (lightning) and a sharp rumbling sound. Thunderstorms are associated with convective clouds (Cumulonimbus) and are more often accompanied by precipitation such as rain, hail or snow. They are usually shortlived and hit on only a small area.
A time series is a collection of observations of well-defined data items obtained through repeated measurements over time.
Networks that allow the bulk transport of electricity at high voltages (220 kilovolts and above) from generators to major demand centres.

Intense low pressure systems which form over warm ocean waters at low latitudes. Tropical cyclones are associated with strong winds, torrential rain and storm surges (in coastal areas). Gale force winds (greater than 63 km/h) must extend more than halfway around the storm near the centre, and winds must persist for at least 6 hours.
A Japanese word for 'harbour wave'. It is used to define a water wave generated by a sudden change in the sea bed resulting from an earthquake, volcanic eruption or submarine landslide.
An opening in the crust of the Earth that allows hot lava, volcanic ash and gases to reach the surface.

The conditions determined by physical, social, economic and environmental factors or processes which increase the susceptibility of an individual, a community, assets or systems to the impacts of hazards.
Dissemination of message signalling imminent hazard which may include advice on protective measures.

The rush of water up a beach after a wave reaches the shoreline. The amount of wave run-up is the vertical distance between the maximum height the rush of water reaches on the beach and the still water level. Wave run-up depends on many factors including wave height, wave period, and the slope and composition of the beach.
The atmospheric variables (temperature, rainfall, humidity, wind speed, etc.) at a particular place and time.

A building is a rigid, fixed and permanent structure which has a roof. Its intended purpose is primarily to house people, plant, machinery, vehicles, goods or livestock. An integral feature of a building's design is the provision for regular access by persons in order to satisfy its intended use. This includes residential buidlings, commerical buildings, industrial buildings and other non-residential buildings.
Fragments of rock ejected into the air by an erupting volcano.
Volcanic ash consists of fragments of rock, mineral crystals, and volcanic glass, created during volcanic eruptions and measuring less than 2 mm in diameter.
